required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Stereotactic Radiation Therapy in Treating Patients With Brain Metastases
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase II Trial of Focal Therapy in the Treatment of Patients With 1-3 Brain Metastases

lead_sponsor.agency: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

clinical_study.source: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

brief_summary.textblock:
RATIONALE: Stereotactic radiation therapy may be able to send x-rays directly to the tumor and cause less damage to normal tissue.
PURPOSE: This phase II trial is study how well stereotactic radiation therapy works in treating patients with brain metastases

detailed_description.textblock:
OBJECTIVES:
Primary
- To determine the neurological death rate following the initiation of conformal stereotactic radiotherapy in patients with 1-3 brain metastases.
Secondary
- To determine the overall survival rate at 6 months.
- To determine the progression-free survival rate or brain metastases recurrence rate at 6 months.
- To determine the time to neurological death, time to systemic death, and Karnofsky decay time.
- To determine the frequency and severity of adverse events associated with conformal stereotactic radiotherapy.
OUTLINE: Patients undergo conformal stereotactic radiotherapy over 5 days to an area including 3 mm around the metastases or the surgical cavity. Patients may receive additional radiotherapy if symptomatic metastases emerge at different sites.
After completion of study treatment, patients are followed up at 1 and 2 months and then every 3 months thereafter.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Patients Dying of Neurological Death, Defined as Dying With Progressive Neurological Dysfunction Regardless of Systemic Disease Status
primary_outcome.description: Neurological death is defined as dying with progressive neurological dysfunction regardless of systemic disease status. Patients wtih severe neurological disability who die of intercurrent illness will also be considered to have died of neurological death.

secondary_outcome.description: Time from enrollment to first date of progressive or recurrent disease. Worsening of neurological symptoms is considered indicative of neurological disease progression. Patients who die of disease-related or treatment-related causes will be considered to have progressed at their date of death; i.e., not be considered 'censored'. PFS will be considered censored only if no progression is noted or if the patient dies of a clearly non-cancer-related event such as accident.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From time of enrollment up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Time from enrollment to date of death directly due to brain metastases. Deaths from other causes including hemorrhage or infection will be considered 'censored' observations in the setting of neurologic improvement or stabilization. If the patient dies of any cause with worsening of neurologic symptoms, the death will be counted as an 'event' or neurological death.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From time of enrollment up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Descriptive analysis will be conducted using Kaplan-Meier survival analysis

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From time of enrollment up to 5 years
secondary_outcome.description: Time from enrollment to the date the patient's Karnofsky performance score drops below 60. If the patient dies of any cause with no documentation of a drop in their Karnofsky score to less than 60, the date of death will be used as the date of worsening of the Karnofsky score. A patient with a Karnofsky score of 60 or greater requires occasional assistance, but is able to care for most of his/her needs. A patient's Karnofsky decay time will be considered censored if the patient is still under follow up with a Karnofsky score of 60 or greater and if the patient dies of a non-cancer-related cause.

clinical_study.condition: Unspecified Adult Solid Tumor, Protocol Specific

intervention.description: Patients undergo conformal stereotatic radiation therapy QD (every day) over 5 days.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Histology-confirmed cancer with 1 to 3 symptomatic brain metastases imaged by MRI/CT scans.
- Have cancer not originating in central nervous system (CNS)
- Karnofsky score of at least 60
- Given written consent
- At least 18 years of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- Prior whole brain radiotherapy or prior focal radiotherapy of the metastasis/es considered for this trial.
- Certain radiosensitive primary tumors such as small cell lung cancer, germ cell tumors, lymphoma, leukemia or multiple myeloma.

overall_official.affiliation: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

facility.name: Arthur G. James Cancer Hospital and Richard J. Solove Research Institute at Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

results_reference.citation: Ammirati M, Kshettry VR, Lamki T, Wei L, Grecula JC. A prospective phase II trial of fractionated stereotactic intensity modulated radiotherapy with or without surgery in the treatment of patients with 1 to 3 newly diagnosed symptomatic brain metastases. Neurosurgery. 2014 Jun;74(6):586-94; discussion 594. doi: 10.1227/NEU.0000000000000325.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

clinical_study.keyword: unspecified adult solid tumor, protocol specific

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Patient recruitment period was June 2007 to March 2010

measure.title: Number of brain metastases
measure.description: Patients with ≥4 brain metastases were eligible for study if only 1 to 3 were symptomatic and all others asymptomatic.

outcome.title: Proportion of Patients Dying of Neurological Death, Defined as Dying With Progressive Neurological Dysfunction Regardless of Systemic Disease Status
outcome.description: Neurological death is defined as dying with progressive neurological dysfunction regardless of systemic disease status. Patients wtih severe neurological disability who die of intercurrent illness will also be considered to have died of neurological death.

outcome.title: Progression-free Survival (PFS)
outcome.description: Time from enrollment to first date of progressive or recurrent disease. Worsening of neurological symptoms is considered indicative of neurological disease progression. Patients who die of disease-related or treatment-related causes will be considered to have progressed at their date of death; i.e., not be considered ‘censored’. PFS will be considered censored only if no progression is noted or if the patient dies of a clearly non-cancer-related event such as accident.

Patients who die of disease-related or treatment-related causes will be considered to have progressed at their date of death; i.e., not be considered ‘censored’. PFS will be considered censored only if no progression is noted or if the patient dies of a clearly non-cancer-related event such as accident.

outcome.description: Time from enrollment to date of death directly due to brain metastases. outcome.title: Karnofsky Decay Time
outcome.description: Time from enrollment to the date the patient’s Karnofsky performance score drops below 60. If the patient dies of any cause with no documentation of a drop in their Karnofsky score to less than 60, the date of death will be used as the date of worsening of the Karnofsky score. A patient with a Karnofsky score of 60 or greater requires occasional assistance, but is able to care for most of his/her needs. A patient’s Karnofsky decay time will be considered censored if the patient is still under follow up with a Karnofsky score of 60 or greater and if the patient dies of a non-cancer-related cause.
outcome.time_frame: From time of enrollment up to 5 years

A patient with a Karnofsky score of 60 or greater requires occasional assistance, but is able to care for most of his/her needs. A patient’s Karnofsky decay time will be considered censored if the patient is still under follow up with a Karnofsky score of 60 or greater and if the patient dies of a non-cancer-related cause.

reported_events.desc: The NCI Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events version 3 [CTCAEv3] was used to access adverse events for patients.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
